description: Recorded since c.1330 as Middle English pronouncen (“to utter, declare officially”), from Old French prononcier, from Latin prōnūntiō, itself from prō- (“forth, out, in public”) + nūntiō (“I announce”) from nūntius (“messenger”).

verbs.description: pronounce (third-person singular simple present pronounces, present participle pronouncing, simple past and past participle pronounced)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To declare formally, officially or ceremoniously.
examples: I hereby pronounce you man and wife.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To declare authoritatively, or as a formal expert opinion.

examples: Despite resuscitative efforts, Mr. Gray was pronounced on 4/19/2015.
The judge had pronounced often before, but never in front of such a crowd.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To sound out (a word or phrase); to articulate.

examples: The Icelandic double l in Eyjafjallajökull is pronounced tl.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To produce the components of speech.
examples: Actors must be able to pronounce perfectly or deliberately disabled.
